sen.j: 素麺（索麺、そうめん）は、小麦粉を原料とした麺のひとつ。
sen.e: Somen is a kind of noodle made from flour.

sen.j: 主に乾麺で流通するため市場では通年入手できるが、冷やして食することが多く、清涼感を求めて夏の麺料理として賞味するのが一般的である。
sen.e: Although available throughout the year because of distribution in the form of dried noodle, somen is generally served cold, and it is common to eat somen as summer noodle for its pleasant coolness.

sen.j: 乾麺については小麦粉に食塩と水を混ぜてよく練り、綿実油などの食用油、もしくは小麦粉やでん粉を塗ってから、よりをかけながら引き延ばして乾燥、熟成させる製法がある。
sen.e: One process of making the dried noodle is to mix flour with salt and water, knead them well, apply cooking oil such as cotton oil, flour, or starch, stretch the mixture while twisting it, and dry it until mature.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: この製法で『手延べ干しめんの日本農林規格』を満たしたものについては「手延素麺（てのべそうめん）」に分類される。
sen.e: One made in this process and satisfying "Japanese Agricultural Standard for dried noodle stretched by hands" is classified as "tenobe somen" (literally meaning hand-stretched somen).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Somen made with this process and satisfying "Japanese Agricultural Standards for dried noodle stretched by hand" is classified as "tenobe somen" (literally meaning hand-stretched somen).

sen.j: 近年では手延べそうめんも大幅に機械化が進んでいる。
sen.e: These days, production of the tenobe somen has been widely mechanized.

sen.j: 小麦粉に食塩と水を混ぜてよく練った生地を帯状に細く切って乾燥させる製法のもので機械にて製造しているものは「機械素麺（きかいそうめん）」に分類される。
sen.e: The somen made by shredding the dough made by mixing flour with salt and water and kneading the mixture and drying the shredded dough using machine is classified as "machine-made somen."

sen.j: 日本農林規格（JAS規格）の『乾めん類品質表示基準』にて、機械麺の場合、素麺の麺の太さは直径1.3mm未満とされている。
sen.e: According to "Quality Labeling Standard for instant noodles " by Japan Agricultural Standards (JAS), thickness of the machine-made somen is defined to be no more than 1.3mm in diameter.

sen.j: ちなみに直径1.3mm以上1.7mm未満はひやむぎ、1.7mm以上はうどんと分類される。
sen.e: For additional information, noodles with the diameter no less than 1.3mm and no more than 1.7mm is defined as cold noodles, and one with the diameter no less than 1.7mm is classified as udon.

sen.e: Although the dried noodle has good keeping quality, it easily gets worms and attention needs to be paid to preserving it.

sen.j: 長期間保存され油分が抜けるとサラサラとした口当たりになり食味が増すとして、虫がつくほど保存したとの意味で「虫つき素麺」と称し珍重される場合もある。
sen.e: Somen preserved so long as until it loses oil becomes smooth with increased eating quality, and it is often valued referred to as "mushitsuki somen" (literally meaning somen with worm) meaning that the somen has been preserved so long to has worms.

sen.j: これについては、素麺の油分は長期保存によって酸化し、むしろ風味を損なうとする意見もある。

sen.j: 生麺・茹で麺等については『生めん類の表示に関する公正競争規約』にて、「この規約で『うどん』とはひらめん、ひやむぎ、そうめんその他名称のいかんを問わず小麦粉に水を加え練り上げた後製麺したもの、又は製麺した後加工したものをいう」となっている。
sen.e: Namamen (fresh noodle) and yudemen (boiled noodle) are defined by "Fair Competition Codes concerning labeling on fresh noodles" as "in this code, 'udon' refers to any noodle produced by adding water to flour and kneading it or the noodle processed after production regardless of the name of the noodle such as hiramen (thin noodle), cold noodle, and somen".

Namamen (fresh noodles) and yudemen (boiled noodles) are defined by "Fair Competition Codes concerning labeling on fresh noodles" as "in this code, 'udon' refers to any noodle produced by adding water to flour and kneading it or the noodles processed after production regardless of the name of the noodles such as hiramen (thin noodles), cold noodles, and somen."

Namamen (fresh noodles) and yudemen (boiled noodles) are defined by "Fair Competition Codes concerning labeling on fresh noodles" as 'in this code, "udon" refers to any noodle produced by adding water to flour and kneading it or the noodles processed after production regardless of the name of the noodles such as hiramen (thin noodles), cold noodles, and somen.'

sen.j: この規約上「素麺」は「うどん」に分類されており、狭義では生麺・茹で麺タイプの素麺はうどんの一種とも解釈できる。
sen.e: This code classifies "somen" as "udon," and therefore namamen and yudemen type of somen can be regarded as a kind of udon in a limited sense.

sen.j: しかし別項にて「一般消費者に誤認されない名称に替えることができる」となっている為、それにより「素麺」の名を使用することも認められており、『生めん類の表示に関する公正競争規約』では一部特産品を除き太さに関する具体的な数値による基準や形状に関する具体的な規定を設けていない。
sen.e: However, because another article describes "the name can be changed so as not to be misidentified by common consumers" thereby allowing to use the name "somen," "Fair Competition Codes concerning labeling on fresh noodles" does not set standards for the thickness by specific values or specific regulations on the shape except a few indigenous products.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, because another article says"the name can be changed so as not to be misidentified by common consumers" thereby allowing the use of the name "somen," "Fair Competition Codes concerning labeling on fresh noodles" do not set standards for the thickness by specific values or specific regulations on the shape except for a few indigenous products.

However, because another article says 'the name can be changed so as not to be misidentified by common consumers' thereby allowing the use of the name 'somen,' "Fair Competition Codes concerning labeling on fresh noodles" do not set standards for the thickness by specific values or specific regulations on the shape except for a few indigenous products.

sen.j: この為、「素麺」、「ひやむぎ」、「細うどん」等は製造・販売業者にて見た目の形状による判断や意向等により、一般消費者に誤認されない範囲で自由に選択して名付けられる。
sen.e: Therefore, "somen," "cold noodle," "thin udon noodle," and the likes can be freely named by their manufacturers and distributors based on their determination by appearance or their intention as long as the common consumers do not misidentify them.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: そのため、この規約に沿った生麺・茹で麺タイプの素麺が実際に製造・販売されている。

sen.e: Before machine-made noodles became popular, somen having a round cross section due to making the dough thinner through the hand-stretching process could be distinguished from cold noodle having a square cross section due to its process of drawing out the dough and shredding it.

sen.j: 祇園社の南北朝時代 (日本)の記録である『祇園執行日記』の康永2年（1343年）7月7日 (旧暦)の条に、麺類を指す言葉として索餅（さくべい）、索麺・素麺（そうめん）と三つの表記があり、これが「そうめん」という言葉の文献上の初出とされている（南北朝時代の「異制定訓往来」が「素麺」の初出という説もある）。
sen.e: In an article of July 7, 1343 (old calendar) in "Gion Shigyonikki" which is a record of Gion-sha Shrine in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan), there are three words indicative of noodles including "sakubei," "sakumen," and "somen," and it is believed to be the first appearance of the word "somen" in writings (there is another theory that the first appearance of "somen" was "Iseiteikinourai" in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts).
